A: You can use a BufferedOutputStream to write the decoded bytes to a file in chunks. This will prevent the whole decoded bytes array from being loaded into memory at once.

```java
String base64 = "base64String";
byte[] decodedBytes = Base64.getDecoder().decode(base64);
try (BufferedOutputStream out = new BufferedOutputStream(new FileOutputStream("output.bin"))) {
    out.write(decodedBytes);
} catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}
```

This code will write the decoded bytes to the file in chunks, which should prevent the OutOfMemoryError.

Please replace "base64String" with your actual base64 string.

Note: This code assumes that the base64 string is correctly formatted and does not contain any errors. If the base64 string is not correctly formatted, the Base64.getDecoder().decode(base64) method will throw an IllegalArgumentException.

Also, make sure that you have the necessary permissions to write to the file system. If you don't, you may get a FileNotFoundException or IOException.

Finally, remember to close the BufferedOutputStream when you're done writing to the file. This can be done by using a try-with-resources statement, as shown in the code above. This will automatically close the BufferedOutputStream and its underlying OutputStream, preventing potential memory leaks.
